skill.name: writing-plans
skill.description: Structured implementation planning for multi-step development tasks. Use when you have a spec or requirements and need to break work into executable steps.
skill.summary: Structured implementation planning for multi-step development tasks. Use when you have a spec or req...
skill.author: CodingCossack

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access patterns. The skill provides guidelines for creating implementation plans and cannot perform actions beyond the AI's existing capabilities.

content.value_statement: Complex development tasks can feel overwhelming when viewed as a whole. This skill breaks specifications into small, verifiable steps that any developer can execute independently, complete with exact file paths and test commands.
actual_capabilities: Create step-by-step implementation plans from requirements
Generate test-first task breakdowns with verification commands
Include exact file paths for all code changes
Follow TDD, DRY, and YAGNI principles
Structure plans for subagent or parallel execution
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Requires user to provide complete requirements or specification
Does not access external APIs or services
Cannot verify that file paths exist without user confirmation

use_cases.title: Break down feature specs
use_cases.description: Transform complex product requirements into executable development steps with test commands.

use_cases.title: Create handoff documents
use_cases.description: Generate detailed plans that developers with no context can follow independently.

use_cases.title: Structure development work
use_cases.description: Plan multi-step implementations for AI agents or human developers to execute.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Feature Plan
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have a feature description
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an implementation plan for [feature name]. Requirements: [list requirements]. Use the writing-plans skill. Save to docs/plans/.

prompt_templates.title: Bug Fix Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a plan to fix this bug: [bug description]. Include test-first approach. Use the writing-plans skill.

prompt_templates.title: Refactoring Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a refactoring plan for [component]. Goal: [refactoring objective]. Include tests that verify behavior is preserved.

prompt_templates.title: Integration Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Plan integration with [API/service]. Include authentication, error handling, and test coverage. Use the writing-plans skill.

output_examples.input: Create an implementation plan for user authentication with email and password login.
output: Structure includes: Goal, Architecture, Tech Stack
Tasks cover: User model, Password hashing, Session management, Login endpoint, Logout endpoint
Each task has: file paths, failing test, implementation, verification command

best_practices: Explore the codebase structure before writing the plan to identify existing patterns
Break tasks into 2-5 minute increments that are independently verifiable
Include exact test code and verification commands in every step
anti_patterns: Writing steps that require multiple unrelated changes at once
Using placeholder text like 'add validation here' instead of actual code
Skipping the initial codebase exploration step

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Writing Plans works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. It requires a context window sufficient for reading specifications and code.

faq.question: What is the ideal plan size?
faq.answer: Plans should contain 5-15 tasks. Larger features should be split into multiple plans that can be executed independently.

faq.question: How does this integrate with git worktrees?
faq.answer: The skill recommends using git worktrees to isolate the planning work. Run using-git-worktrees skill first if no worktree exists.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only generates text plans. It does not access files, networks, or external services. Your code and data remain on your machine.

faq.question: Why are my plans failing to execute?
faq.answer: Common issues include: missing tech stack info, non-existent file paths, or commands that require a different working directory. Verify paths and context before execution.

faq.question: How is this different from regular task lists?
faq.answer: Unlike simple task lists, this skill creates executable plans with actual code snippets, test commands, and commit messages that developers can follow verbatim.
